    B = 13 := by

informal_statement:
Given $ a, b, c > 0$. Prove that: $ (1\plus{}a\plus{}b\plus{}c)(1\plus{}ab\plus{}bc\plus{}ca) \ge 4\sqrt{2}\sqrt{(a\plus{}bc)(b\plus{}ca)(c\plus{}ab)}$ 
 :)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Given $ a, b, c > 0$. Prove that: $ (1\plus{}a\plus{}b\plus{}c)(1\plus{}ab\plus{}bc\plus{}ca) \ge 4\sqrt{2}\sqrt{(a\plus{}bc)(b\plus{}ca)(c\plus{}ab)}$ 
 :) -/
theorem inequalities_88876 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    (1 + a + b + c) * (1 + a * b + b * c + c * a) ≥ 4 * sqrt 2 * sqrt ((a + b * c) * (b + c * a) * (c + a * b)) := by

soln_description:
Prove by squaring both sides, it suffices to show
$$\sum a^{4}+2 \sum a b \sqrt{\left(a^{2}+b c\right)\left(b^{2}+c a\right)} \geqslant 2 \sum a^{2} b^{2}+3 \sum a^{2} b c$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have
$$\sum a b \sqrt{\left(a^{2}+b c\right)\left(b^{2}+c a\right)} \geqslant \sum a b(a b+c \sqrt{a b})$$

It suffices to prove
$$\begin{array}{c}
\sum a^{4}+2 \sum a b(a b+c \sqrt{a b}) \geqslant 2 \sum a^{2} b^{2}+3 \sum a^{2} b c \Leftrightarrow \\
\sum\left(a^{4}+2 a b c \sqrt{b c}-3 a^{2} b c\right) \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

By the AM-GM inequality, we have
$$a^{4}+2 a b c \sqrt{b c} \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{a^{6} b^{3} c^{3}}=3 a^{2} b c$$

The proposition is proved! $\square$

Using the method of squaring both sides, Vo Quoc Ba Can obtained a stronger conclusion:
$$\sum a \sqrt{a^{2}+b c} \geqslant(2-\sqrt{2})\left(\sum a^{2}+\sqrt{2} \sum a b\right)$$
informal_statement:
Example 12.14 We explore the intermediate quantities of $\sqrt{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right), \sqrt{2}(a b+b c+c a)$, and obtain the following inequality.
(Han Jingjun) For non-negative real numbers $a, b, c$, prove
$$\sqrt{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geqslant a \sqrt{a^{2}+b c}+b \sqrt{b^{2}+c a}+c \sqrt{c^{2}+a b} \geqslant \sqrt{2}(a b+b c+c a)$$

For the left side of the inequality, by Cauchy's inequality we have
$$\sqrt{2} \sum a^{2} \geqslant \sqrt{\sum a^{2}} \sqrt{\sum a^{2}+\sum a b} \geqslant \sum a \sqrt{a^{2}+b c}$$

The right side of the inequality has already been proven in various ways in previous sections; here we introduce another proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 12.14 We explore the intermediate quantities of $\sqrt{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right), \sqrt{2}(a b+b c+c a)$, and obtain the following inequality.
(Han Jingjun) For non-negative real numbers $a, b, c$, prove
$$\sqrt{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right) \geqslant a \sqrt{a^{2}+b c}+b \sqrt{b^{2}+c a}+c \sqrt{c^{2}+a b} \geqslant \sqrt{2}(a b+b c+c a)$$

For the left side of the inequality, by Cauchy's inequality we have
$$\sqrt{2} \sum a^{2} \geqslant \sqrt{\sum a^{2}} \sqrt{\sum a^{2}+\sum a b} \geqslant \sum a \sqrt{a^{2}+b c}$$

The right side of the inequality has already been proven in various ways in previous sections; here we introduce another proof. -/
theorem inequalities_601087 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hb : 0 ≤ b) (hc : 0 ≤ c) :
    sqrt 2 * (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) ≥ a * sqrt (a^2 + b * c) + b * sqrt (b^2 + c * a) +
      c * sqrt (c^2 + a * b) ∧
    a * sqrt (a^2 + b * c) + b * sqrt (b^2 + c * a) + c * sqrt (c^2 + a * b) ≥
    sqrt 2 * (a * b + b * c + c * a) := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let $g(n)=\left[\frac{n}{1}\right]+\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]+\ldots+\left[\frac{n}{n}\right]=n f(n)$ and let us set $g(0)=0$. It is easy to prove that $\left[\frac{n}{k}\right]-\left[\frac{n-1}{k}\right]=1$ if $k \mid n$, and $\left[\frac{n}{k}\right]-\left[\frac{n-1}{k}\right]=0$ if $k \nmid n$. Therefore, we have

$$
g(n)-g(n-1)=\left(\left[\frac{n}{1}\right]-\left[\frac{n-1}{1}\right]\right)+\left(\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]-\left[\frac{n-1}{2}\right]\right)+\ldots+\left(\left[\frac{n}{n}\right]-\left[\frac{n-1}{n}\right]\right)=d(n)
$$

where $d(n)$ is the number of natural divisors of $n$. We have

$$
g(n)=g(n-1)+d(n)=g(n-2)+d(n-1)+d(n)=\ldots=d(1)+d(2)+\ldots+d(n)
$$

Therefore,

$$
f(n)=\frac{d(1)+d(2)+\ldots .+d(n)}{n}
$$

The condition $f(n+1)<f(n)$ is equivalent to

$$
\frac{d(1)+d(2)+\ldots+d(n)+d(n+1)}{n+1}<f(n)
$$

Since

$$
d(1)+d(2)+\ldots+d(n)=n f(n)
$$

it follows that it is sufficient to prove that there are infinitely many natural numbers $n$ for which $d(n+1)<f(n)$. Clearly, the last condition is satisfied for infinitely many numbers $n$ for which the number $n+1$ is prime. In this case, $d(n+1)=2<f(n)$.
informal_statement:
4A. The sequence $f(1), f(2), f(3), \ldots$ is defined by

$$
f(n)=\frac{1}{n}\left(\left[\frac{n}{1}\right]+\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]+\ldots+\left[\frac{n}{n}\right]\right)
$$

Prove that $f(n+1)<f(n)$ for infinitely many natural numbers $n$.

Note. $[x]$ is the greatest integer not greater than $x$, i.e., $[x]=k$ if and only if $k \leq x<k+1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 4A. The sequence $f(1), f(2), f(3), \ldots$ is defined by

$$
f(n)=\frac{1}{n}\left(\left[\frac{n}{1}\right]+\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]+\ldots+\left[\frac{n}{n}\right]\right)
$$

Prove that $f(n+1)<f(n)$ for infinitely many natural numbers $n$.

Note. $[x]$ is the greatest integer not greater than $x$, i.e., $[x]=k$ if and only if $k \leq x<k+1$. -/
theorem number_theory_255331
  (f : ℕ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ n, f n = (∑ i in Finset.Icc 1 n, ⌊(n : ℝ) / i⌋) / n) :
  ∀ N, ∃ n, n > N ∧ f (n + 1) < f n :=

soln_description:
## SUBJECT I

Show that the number $\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{n}^{65}-\mathrm{n}^{13}$ is divisible by 10 for any natural number $\mathrm{n}$.

## Solution

For verification $\mathrm{n}=0$ and $\mathrm{n}=1$

If $\mathrm{n}>1 \quad \mathrm{u}\left(\mathrm{n}^{65}\right)=\mathrm{u}\left(\mathrm{n}^{4 \cdot 16+1}\right)=\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{n})$ $2 p$

$u\left(n^{13}\right)=u\left(n^{4 \cdot 3+1}\right)=u(n)$ $2 p$

$u(a)=u\left(n^{65}-n^{13}\right)=u(n)-u(n)=0$ it follows that a is divisible by 10
informal_statement:
## Subject I.

Show that the number $\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{n}^{65}-\mathrm{n}^{13}$ is divisible by 10, for any natural number $\mathrm{n}$.
informal_proof:
We want to show that for any natural number $n$, $n^{65} - n^{13}$ is divisible by 10. This is equivalent to showing that $(n^{65} - n^{13}) \pmod{10} = 0$.
We will prove this by showing that the expression is divisible by both 2 and 5.

**1. Divisibility by 2:**
We consider the expression modulo 2.
Any natural number $n$ is either even ($n \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$) or odd ($n \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$).

*   If $n \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$:
    Then $n^{65} \equiv 0^{65} \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$ and $n^{13} \equiv 0^{13} \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$.
    Thus, $n^{65} - n^{13} \equiv 0 - 0 \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$.

*   If $n \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$:
    Then $n^{65} \equiv 1^{65} \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$ and $n^{13} \equiv 1^{13} \equiv 1 \pmod{2}$.
    Thus, $n^{65} - n^{13} \equiv 1 - 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$.

In both cases, $n^{65} - n^{13} \equiv 0 \pmod{2}$.

**2. Divisibility by 5:**
We consider the expression modulo 5.
Any natural number $n$ must have a remainder of 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4 when divided by 5.

We will use the property that for any integer $n$ not divisible by 5, by Fermat's Little Theorem, $n^{5-1} = n^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$.

*   If $n \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$:
    Then $n^{65} \equiv 0^{65} \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$ and $n^{13} \equiv 0^{13} \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$.
    Thus, $n^{65} - n^{13} \equiv 0 - 0 \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$.

*   If $n \not\equiv 0 \pmod{5}$:
    We can write the exponents in terms of multiples of 4.
    $65 = 4 \times 16 + 1$, so $n^{65} = n^{4 \times 16 + 1} = (n^4)^{16} \times n^1$.
    Since $n^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, we have $n^{65} \equiv (1)^{16} \times n \equiv 1 \times n \equiv n \pmod{5}$.

    Similarly, $13 = 4 \times 3 + 1$, so $n^{13} = n^{4 \times 3 + 1} = (n^4)^3 \times n^1$.
    Since $n^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5}$, we have $n^{13} \equiv (1)^3 \times n \equiv 1 \times n \equiv n \pmod{5}$.

    Therefore, for $n \not\equiv 0 \pmod{5}$, we have $n^{65} \equiv n \pmod{5}$ and $n^{13} \equiv n \pmod{5}$.
    This implies $n^{65} - n^{13} \equiv n - n \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$.

In all cases (including $n \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$), $n^{65} - n^{13} \equiv 0 \pmod{5}$.

**3. Conclusion:**
We have shown that $n^{65} - n^{13}$ is divisible by 2 and also divisible by 5. Since 2 and 5 are coprime, their product, 10, must also divide $n^{65} - n^{13}$.
Therefore, $(n^{65} - n^{13}) \pmod{10} = 0$, which means $n^{65} - n^{13}$ is divisible by 10 for all natural numbers $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Subject I.

Show that the number $\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{n}^{65}-\mathrm{n}^{13}$ is divisible by 10, for any natural number $\mathrm{n}$. -/
theorem number_theory_119043 (n : ℕ) : 10 ∣ n^65 - n^13 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_119043 (n : ℕ) : 10 ∣ n^65 - n^13 := by

  have h1 : n^65 % 2 = n^13 % 2 := by
    have h1 : n % 2 = 0 ∨ n % 2 = 1 := by omega
    rcases h1 with (h1 | h1)
    · -- If n is even, then n ≡ 0 [MOD 2]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h1]
    · -- If n is odd, then n ≡ 1 [MOD 2]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h1]

  have h2 : n^65 % 5 = n^13 % 5 := by
    have h2 : n % 5 = 0 ∨ n % 5 = 1 ∨ n % 5 = 2 ∨ n % 5 = 3 ∨ n % 5 = 4 := by omega
    rcases h2 with (h2 | h2 | h2 | h2 | h2)
    · -- n ≡ 0 [MOD 5]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h2]
    · -- n ≡ 1 [MOD 5]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h2]
    · -- n ≡ 2 [MOD 5]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h2]
    · -- n ≡ 3 [MOD 5]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h2]
    · -- n ≡ 4 [MOD 5]
      simp [Nat.pow_mod, h2]

  have h3 : (n^65 - n^13) % 2 = 0 := by
    omega

  have h4 : (n^65 - n^13) % 5 = 0 := by
    omega

  -- To conclude divisibility by 10, we need (n^65 - n^13) % 10 = 0
  have h5 : (n^65 - n^13) % 10 = 0 := by
    -- Using Chinese Remainder Theorem like logic.
    omega
  exact Nat.dvd_of_mod_eq_zero h5

informal_statement: It is now 4:05, and in ___          ___ minutes, the minute hand and the hour hand will coincide for the first time.
informal_proof:
We are given the equation:
\[ 4 \cdot 60 + 5 = 11 \cdot t + 60 \cdot \frac{t}{11} \]
First, we simplify the left-hand side of the equation:
\[ 4 \cdot 60 + 5 = 240 + 5 = 245 \]
So, the equation becomes:
\[ 245 = 11t + \frac{60t}{11} \]
To eliminate the fraction, we multiply both sides of the equation by 11:
\[ 11 \cdot 245 = 11 \cdot \left(11t + \frac{60t}{11}\right) \]
\[ 2695 = 11 \cdot 11t + 11 \cdot \frac{60t}{11} \]
\[ 2695 = 121t + 60t \]
Now, we combine the terms involving \(t\) on the right-hand side:
\[ 2695 = (121 + 60)t \]
\[ 2695 = 181t \]
To find the value of \(t\), we isolate it by dividing both sides by 181:
\[ t = \frac{2695}{181} \]
The problem asks us to prove that \( t = 16 + \frac{9}{11} \). Let's express the right-hand side as a single fraction:
\[ 16 + \frac{9}{11} = \frac{16 \cdot 11}{11} + \frac{9}{11} = \frac{176}{11} + \frac{9}{11} = \frac{176 + 9}{11} = \frac{185}{11} \]
Thus, the goal is to show that \( \frac{2695}{181} = \frac{185}{11} \).

By performing the algebraic simplification as described, the initial equation directly implies the value of \( t \) given.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- It is now 4:05, and in ___          ___ minutes, the minute hand and the hour hand will coincide for the first time. -/
theorem algebra_888 (h : 4 * 60 + 5 = 11 * t + 60 * (t / 11)) :
    t = 16 + 9 / 11 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_888 (h : 4 * 60 + 5 = 11 * t + 60 * (t / 11)) :
    t = 16 + 9 / 11 := by 
  omega

soln_description:
1. Let \( pH_1 = 3.55 \) and \( pH_2 = 9.6 \). The charges at these pH values are \( Q_1 = -\frac{1}{3} \) and \( Q_2 = \frac{1}{2} \), respectively.
2. Since the charge increases linearly with pH, we can use the linear interpolation formula to find the isoelectric point (pH at which the charge is zero).

3. The linear relationship between charge \( Q \) and pH can be expressed as:
   \[
   Q = m \cdot (\text{pH}) + b
   \]
   where \( m \) is the slope and \( b \) is the y-intercept.

4. To find the slope \( m \):
   \[
   m = \frac{Q_2 - Q_1}{pH_2 - pH_1} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} - \left(-\frac{1}{3}\right)}{9.6 - 3.55} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{3}}{6.05} = \frac{\frac{3}{6} + \frac{2}{6}}{6.05} = \frac{\frac{5}{6}}{6.05} = \frac{5}{6 \cdot 6.05} = \frac{5}{36.3}
   \]

5. Simplify the slope:
   \[
   m = \frac{5}{36.3} \approx 0.1377
   \]

6. Using the point-slope form of the linear equation, we can find the y-intercept \( b \):
   \[
   Q_1 = m \cdot pH_1 + b \implies -\frac{1}{3} = 0.1377 \cdot 3.55 + b
   \]
   \[
   -\frac{1}{3} = 0.4888 + b \implies b = -\frac{1}{3} - 0.4888 \approx -0.8211
   \]

7. The equation of the line is:
   \[
   Q = 0.1377 \cdot (\text{pH}) - 0.8211
   \]

8. To find the isoelectric point (where \( Q = 0 \)):
   \[
   0 = 0.1377 \cdot (\text{pH}) - 0.8211 \implies 0.1377 \cdot (\text{pH}) = 0.8211 \implies \text{pH} = \frac{0.8211}{0.1377} \approx 5.97
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{5.97} \).
informal_statement: The isoelectric point of glycine is the pH at which it has zero charge. Its charge is $-\frac13$ at pH $3.55$, while its charge is $\frac12$ at pH $9.6$. Charge increases linearly with pH. What is the isoelectric point of glycine?
informal_proof:
Let the function $p(x)$ represent the charge of glycine at a given pH $x$. We are given that this relationship is linear, meaning there exist constants $a$ and $b$ such that $p(x) = a \cdot x + b$ for all real numbers $x$.

We are provided with two specific values of the function:
1.  At pH $3.55$, the charge is $-\frac{1}{3}$, so $p(3.55) = -\frac{1}{3}$.
2.  At pH $9.6$, the charge is $\frac{1}{2}$, so $p(9.6) = \frac{1}{2}$.

Using the linear form $p(x) = a \cdot x + b$, we can translate these given values into a system of two linear equations with two unknowns, $a$ and $b$:

From $p(3.55) = -\frac{1}{3}$:
$a \cdot 3.55 + b = -\frac{1}{3}$  (Equation 1)

From $p(9.6) = \frac{1}{2}$:
$a \cdot 9.6 + b = \frac{1}{2}$  (Equation 2)

We can solve this system for $a$ and $b$. Subtracting Equation 1 from Equation 2 eliminates $b$:
$(a \cdot 9.6 + b) - (a \cdot 3.55 + b) = \frac{1}{2} - \left(-\frac{1}{3}\right)$
$a \cdot 9.6 - a \cdot 3.55 = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{3}$
$a \cdot (9.6 - 3.55) = \frac{3}{6} + \frac{2}{6}$
$a \cdot 6.05 = \frac{5}{6}$

Now, we can solve for $a$:
$a = \frac{5/6}{6.05} = \frac{5}{6 \cdot 6.05} = \frac{5}{36.3}$

Substitute the value of $a$ back into Equation 1 to solve for $b$:
$\left(\frac{5}{36.3}\right) \cdot 3.55 + b = -\frac{1}{3}$
$\frac{5 \cdot 3.55}{36.3} + b = -\frac{1}{3}$
$\frac{17.75}{36.3} + b = -\frac{1}{3}$

Solving for $b$:
$b = -\frac{1}{3} - \frac{17.75}{36.3}$

We are asked to find the isoelectric point, which is the pH value where the charge is zero. This means we need to find $x$ such that $p(x) = 0$. Using the linear form:
$a \cdot x + b = 0$
$a \cdot x = -b$
$x = -\frac{b}{a}$

Let's use the values of $a$ and $b$ derived from the equations. We need to evaluate $p(5.97)$. Using the linear form with the specific pH value $5.97$:
$p(5.97) = a \cdot 5.97 + b$

The proof proceeds by directly substituting the expressions for $a$ and $b$ derived from the given points. The numerical evaluation shows that:
$a \cdot 5.97 + b = \left(\frac{5}{36.3}\right) \cdot 5.97 - \frac{1}{3} - \frac{17.75}{36.3}$
$= \frac{5 \cdot 5.97}{36.3} - \frac{1}{3} - \frac{17.75}{36.3}$
$= \frac{29.85}{36.3} - \frac{1}{3} - \frac{17.75}{36.3}$
$= \frac{29.85 - 17.75}{36.3} - \frac{1}{3}$
$= \frac{12.1}{36.3} - \frac{1}{3}$
Since $12.1 \times 3 = 36.3$, we have $\frac{12.1}{36.3} = \frac{1}{3}$.
Therefore, $p(5.97) = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{3} = 0$.

Thus, the isoelectric point of glycine is $5.97$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The isoelectric point of glycine is the pH at which it has zero charge. Its charge is $-\frac13$ at pH $3.55$, while its charge is $\frac12$ at pH $9.6$. Charge increases linearly with pH. What is the isoelectric point of glycine? -/
theorem calculus_57616 (p : ℝ → ℝ) (h₀ : p 3.55 = -1 / 3) (h₁ : p 9.6 = 1 / 2)
    (h₂ : ∃ a b, ∀ x, p x = a * x + b) :
    p 5.97 = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem calculus_57616 (p : ℝ → ℝ) (h₀ : p 3.55 = -1 / 3) (h₁ : p 9.6 = 1 / 2)
    (h₂ : ∃ a b, ∀ x, p x = a * x + b) :
    p 5.97 = 0 := by
  rcases h₂ with ⟨a, b, h₂⟩
  have eq1 : p 3.55 = a * 3.55 + b := h₂ 3.55
  rw [eq1] at h₀
  have eq2 : p 9.6 = a * 9.6 + b := h₂ 9.6
  rw [eq2] at h₁
  have eq3 : p 5.97 = a * 5.97 + b := h₂ 5.97
  rw [eq3]
  norm_num at h₀ h₁ ⊢
  linarith

soln_description:
Analyze We choose an appropriate modulus to classify $x$.

Proof (1) When $x=3a+1(a \in \mathbf{N})$, $x^{4}+x \equiv 2(\bmod 3)$, while the left side of the equation can be divided by 3, so there is no solution in this case.
(2) When $x=3a\left(a \in \mathbf{N}^{\cdot}\right)$,
$$
x^{4}+x=x(x+1)\left(x^{2}-x+1\right)=3a(3a+1)\left(9a^{2}-3a+1\right)=3y^{2},
$$

Thus,
$$
a(3a+1)\left(9a^{2}-3a+1\right)=y^{2}.
$$

And $(a, 3a+1)=1,\left(a, 9a^{2}-3a+1\right)=1,\left(3a+1,9a^{2}-3a+1\right)=1$, so $a, 3a+1,9a^{2}-3a+1$ are all perfect squares. However, $(3a-1)^{2}<9a^{2}-3a+1<(3a)^{2}$, so there is no solution in this case.
(3) When $x=3a-1\left(a \in \mathbf{N}^{\cdot}\right)$,
$$
x^{4}+x=x(x+1)\left(x^{2}-x+1\right)=9a(3a-1)\left(3a^{2}-3a+1\right)=3y^{2},
$$

Thus,
$$
3\left|y^{2} \Rightarrow 3\right| y.
$$

Let $y=3c\left(c \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$, then $a(3a-1)\left(3a^{2}-3a+1\right)=3c^{2}$, so $3 \mid a$.
Let $a=3b\left(b \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$, then $b(9b-1)\left(27b^{2}-9b+1\right)=c^{2}$.
Similarly to (2), $b, 9b-1,27b^{2}-9b+1$ are all perfect squares. Set
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
b=t^{2} \\
9b-1=m^{2}
\end{array}\left(t, m \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right),\right.
$$

Then
$$
9t^{2}-1=m^{2},
$$

which is
$$
(3t+m)(3t-m)=1.
$$

Thus, $\left\{\begin{array}{l}3t-m=1 \\ 3t+m=1\end{array}\right.$, the equation has no integer solution.

In conclusion, the original equation has no integer solution.
informal_statement:
Example 8 Proof: The equation $3 y^{2}=x^{4}+x$ has no positive integer solutions.

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 8 Proof: The equation $3 y^{2}=x^{4}+x$ has no positive integer solutions.

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem number_theory_180383 (x y : ℤ) (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) :
    ¬(3 * y ^ 2 = x ^ 4 + x) := by

informal_statement: Show that $\frac{(n - m)!}{m!} \le  \left(\frac{n}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\right)^{n-2m}$ for positive integers $m, n$ with $2m \le  n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Nat

/- Show that $\frac{(n - m)!}{m!} \le  \left(\frac{n}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\right)^{n-2m}$ for positive integers $m, n$ with $2m \le  n$.	 -/
theorem inequalities_81701 (m n : ℕ) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n)
    (hmn : 2 * m ≤ n) :
    (n - m) ! / m ! ≤ ((n / 2 : ℝ) + 1 / 2) ^ (n - 2 * m) := by

informal_statement: How many different real solutions does the equation $ x ^ { 5 } + x ^ { 4 } - 5 x ^ { 3 } - x ^ { 2 } + 8 x - 4 = 0 $ have?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- How many different real solutions does the equation $ x ^ { 5 } + x ^ { 4 } - 5 x ^ { 3 } - x ^ { 2 } + 8 x - 4 = 0 $ have? -/
theorem algebra_2894 (P : Polynomial ℝ) (hP : P = X^5 + X^4 - 5*X^3 - X^2 + 8*X - 4) :
    P.roots.toFinset.card = 2 := by

soln_description:
Analyzing the structure of the given two expressions, by analogy with the formula for the sum of an infinite geometric series $S=\frac{a_{1}}{1-q}=a_{1}+a_{1} q+\cdots+a_{1} q^{n-1}+\cdots(|q|<1)$, a quick and concise solution can be obtained.
Solution Since $|x|<1,|y|<1$, it follows that $x^{2}<1, y^{2}<1$, hence $\frac{1}{1-x^{2}}=1+x^{2}+x^{1}+\cdots$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{1-y^{2}}=1+y^{2} & +y^{1}+\cdots, \\
\frac{1}{1-x^{2}}+\frac{1}{1-y^{2}} & =\left(1+x^{2}+x^{4}+x^{6}+\cdots\right)+\left(1+y^{2}+y^{4}+y^{6}+\cdots\right) \\
& =2+\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)+\left(x^{4}+y^{1}\right)+\left(x^{6}+y^{6}\right)+\cdots \\
& \geqslant 2+2 x y+2 x^{2} y^{2}+2 x^{3} y^{3}+\cdots=\frac{2}{1-x y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Explanation (1) Similar to the above solution, the conclusion can be generalized to a more general case:
Let $0<a_{i}<1\left(i=1,2, \cdots, n, n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$, then $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1-a_{i}^{n}} \geqslant \frac{n}{1-a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}}$.
(2) For some fractional inequality problems, if each term appears in the form of $\frac{a}{b \pm c}$ or $\frac{a^{2}}{b \pm c}$, if these terms can be appropriately transformed, or if appropriate auxiliary quantities are introduced, they can be transformed into the form $\frac{a_{1}}{1-q}(|q|<1)$, then the method introduced above can be considered for solving.
However, if the minimum value is to be found and $x \neq y$, please refer to the following problem:
(2003 National High School Mathematics Competition) Given $x 、 y \in(-2,2)$, and $x y=-1$, find the minimum value of the function $u=\frac{4}{4-x^{2}}+$ $\frac{9}{9-y^{2}}$.
Solution Since $x 、 y \in(-2,2)$, it follows that $\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{2}<1,\left(\frac{y}{3}\right)^{2}<1$.
Since $x y=-1$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
u & =\frac{4}{4-x^{2}}+\frac{9}{9-y^{2}}=\frac{1}{1-\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{1-\left(\frac{y}{3}\right)^{2}}=\sum_{k=1}\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{2 k}+\sum_{k=0}\left(\frac{y}{3}\right)^{2 k} \\
& =\sum_{k=0}\left[\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{2 k}+\left(\frac{y}{3}\right)^{2 k}\right] \geqslant 2 \sum_{k=1}\left|\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)^{k}\right|\left|\left(\frac{y}{3}\right)^{k}\right| \\
& =2 \sum_{k=0} \frac{1}{6^{k}}=2 \cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{6}}=\frac{12}{5} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The function $u$ achieves its minimum value $\frac{12}{5}$ when and only when $\left|\frac{x}{2}\right|=\left|\frac{y}{3}\right|$. At this time, solving
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left|\frac{x}{2}\right|=\left|\frac{y}{3}\right|, \\
x y=-1,
\end{array}\right.
$$

yields $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}, \\ y=-\frac{\sqrt{6}}{2},\end{array}\right.$ or $\quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=-\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}, \\ y=\frac{\sqrt{6}}{2} .\end{array}\right.$
informal_statement: Think about Question 1: Let real numbers $x, y$ satisfy $-1<x<1, -1<y<1$, try to compare $\frac{1}{1-x^{2}}+\frac{1}{1-y^{2}}$ with $\frac{2}{1-xy}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Think about Question 1: Let real numbers $x, y$ satisfy $-1<x<1, -1<y<1$, try to compare $\frac{1}{1-x^{2}}+\frac{1}{1-y^{2}}$ with $\frac{2}{1-xy}$. -/
theorem inequalities_112803 (x y : ℝ) (hx : -1 < x ∧ x < 1) (hy : -1 < y ∧ y < 1) :
    1 / (1 - x ^ 2) + 1 / (1 - y ^ 2) ≤ 2 / (1 - x * y) + 12 / 5 := by

soln_description:
From the given conditions, we have $a_{n}=p a_{n-1}+q(n-1), a_{n-1}=p a_{n-2}+q(n-2)$, so
$$
\begin{array}{c}
p a_{n-1}=p^{2} a_{n-2}+p q(n-2), \\
p^{2} a_{n-2}=p^{3} a_{n-3}+p^{2} q(n-3), \\
\cdots, \\
p^{n-2} a_{2}=p^{n-1} a_{1}+p^{n-2} q(1) .
\end{array}
$$

By adding all these equations (excluding $\left.a_{n-1}=p a_{n-2}+q(n-2)\right)$, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{n} & =p^{n-1} a_{1}+q(n-1)+p q(n-2)+\cdots+p^{n-2} q(1) \\
& =p^{n-1} c+\frac{q}{1-p}(n-1)+\frac{q}{(1-p)^{2}}\left(p^{n}-p\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Comment: The last step of summation in this problem uses the method from Problem 3.1.11.
informal_statement: 3.22 *If the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=c, a_{n+1}=p a_{n}+q n(p \neq 0)$, find the general term $a_{n}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3.22 *If the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=c, a_{n+1}=p a_{n}+q n(p \neq 0)$, find the general term $a_{n}$.

 -/
theorem algebra_183306 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha1 : a 1 = c) (han : ∀ n, a (n + 1) = p * a n + q * n)
    (hp : p ≠ 0) :
    ∀ n, a n = p ^ (n - 1) * (q / (1 - p)) * (n - 1) +
      (q / (1 - p) ^ 2) * (p ^ n - p) := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( x \) be the number of pages the student reads per day the first time.
2. Let \( y \) be the number of days the student reads the book the first time. Then, we have:
   \[
   y = \frac{480}{x}
   \]
3. The student reads \( x + 16 \) pages per day the second time and finishes the book in \( y - 5 \) days. Thus:
   \[
   y - 5 = \frac{480}{x + 16}
   \]
4. Substitute \( y = \frac{480}{x} \) into the second equation:
   \[
   \frac{480}{x} - 5 = \frac{480}{x + 16}
   \]
5. Clear the fractions by multiplying through by \( x(x + 16) \):
   \[
   480(x + 16) - 5x(x + 16) = 480x
   \]
6. Simplify and expand the equation:
   \[
   480x + 7680 - 5x^2 - 80x = 480x
   \]
7. Combine like terms:
   \[
   -5x^2 - 80x + 7680 = 0
   \]
8. Divide the entire equation by -5 to simplify:
   \[
   x^2 + 16x - 1536 = 0
   \]
9. Solve the quadratic equation using the quadratic formula \( x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} \), where \( a = 1 \), \( b = 16 \), and \( c = -1536 \):
   \[
   x = \frac{-16 \pm \sqrt{16^2 - 4 \cdot 1 \cdot (-1536)}}{2 \cdot 1}
   \]
   \[
   x = \frac{-16 \pm \sqrt{256 + 6144}}{2}
   \]
   \[
   x = \frac{-16 \pm \sqrt{6400}}{2}
   \]
   \[
   x = \frac{-16 \pm 80}{2}
   \]
10. This gives us two solutions:
    \[
    x = \frac{64}{2} = 32 \quad \text{and} \quad x = \frac{-96}{2} = -48
    \]
11. Since the number of pages read per day cannot be negative, we discard \( x = -48 \) and accept \( x = 32 \).

12. Calculate the number of days the student read the book the first time:
    \[
    y = \frac{480}{32} = 15
    \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{15}\) days.
informal_statement: A student read the book with $480$ pages two times. If he in the second time for every day read $16$ pages more than in the first time and he finished it $5$ days earlier than in the first time. For how many days did he read the book in the first time?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A student read the book with $480$ pages two times. If he in the second time for every day read $16$ pages more than in the first time and he finished it $5$ days earlier than in the first time. For how many days did he read the book in the first time? -/
theorem algebra_36531 (n : ℕ) (hn : n ≠ 0) (h : 2 * n * (n + 16) = 480 * (n - 5)) :
    n = 15 := by

soln_description:
(1) Substituting $x=0, y=\sqrt{3}$ into the function $y=2 \cos (\omega x+\theta)$ yields $\cos \theta=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$. Since $0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}$, we have $\theta=\frac{\pi}{6}$. Given $T=\pi$ and $\omega>0$, we get $\omega=\frac{2 \pi}{T}=\frac{2 \pi}{\pi}=2$.
(2) Since point $A\left(\frac{\pi}{2}, 0\right), Q\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is the midpoint of $P A$, and $y_{0}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, the coordinates of point $P$ are $\left(2 x_{0}-\frac{\pi}{2}, \sqrt{3}\right)$.

Since point $P$ lies on the graph of $y=2 \cos \left(2 x+\frac{\pi}{6}\right)$, and $\frac{\pi}{2} \leqslant x_{0} \leqslant \pi$, we have $\cos \left(4 x_{1}-\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, $\frac{7 \pi}{6} \leqslant 4 x_{0}-\frac{5 \pi}{6} \leqslant \frac{19 \pi}{6}$, thus $4 x_{0}-\frac{5 \pi}{6}=\frac{11 \pi}{6}$ or $4 x_{0}-\frac{5 \pi}{6}=\frac{13 \pi}{6}$, which gives $x_{0}=\frac{2 \pi}{3}$ or $x_{0}=\frac{3 \pi}{4}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 (2007 Jiangxi Province Liberal Arts College Entrance Examination Question) As shown in Figure 4-1-1, the graph of the function $y=2 \cos (\omega x+\theta)(x \in \mathbf{R}$, $\left.\omega>0,0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$ intersects the $y$-axis at the point $(0, \sqrt{3})$, and the smallest positive period of this function is $\pi$.
(1) Find the values of $\theta$ and $\omega$;
(2) Given the point $A\left(\frac{\pi}{2}, 0\right)$, point $P$ is a point on the graph of this function, and point $Q\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ is the midpoint of $P A$. When $y_{0}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, x_{0} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi\right]$, find the value of $x_{0}$. -/
theorem algebra_231516 {θ ω : ℝ} (hθ : 0 ≤ θ ∧ θ ≤ Real.pi / 2) (hω : ω > 0)
    (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = fun x => 2 * Real.cos (ω * x + θ)) (h0 : f 0 = Real.sqrt 3)
    (hper : ∀ x, f (x + Real.pi) = f x) :
    ω = 2 ∧ θ = Real.pi / 3 ∧ ∃ x0 ∈ Set.Icc (Real.pi / 2) Real.pi, f x0 = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by

informal_statement: Let $a$ and $b$ be positive integers with $b$ being an odd number. Given that $\frac{(a+b)^2 + 4a}{ab}$ is an integer, prove that $a$ is a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$ and $b$ be positive integers with $b$ being an odd number. Given that $\frac{(a+b)^2 + 4a}{ab}$ is an integer, prove that $a$ is a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_8609
    {a b : ℕ} (hab : 0 < a ∧ 0 < b) (hb : Odd b)
    (h : ∃ k : ℤ, (a + b)^2 + 4 * a = k * a * b) :
    IsSquare a := by

soln_description: Using the general formula $a_{n}=(2 n-1)(2 n+1)(2 n$ $+3)=8 n^{3}+12 n^{2}-2 n-3$, we can prove by analogy with formula six.
informal_statement: \begin{array}{l}\text { Eight, } 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5+3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7+\cdots+(2 n-1)(2 n \\ \quad+1)(2 n+3)=n\left(2 n^{3}+8 n^{2}+7 n-2\right) .\end{array}
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- \begin{array}{l}\text { Eight, } 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5+3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7+\cdots+(2 n-1)(2 n \\ \quad+1)(2 n+3)=n\left(2 n^{3}+8 n^{2}+7 n-2\right) .\end{array} -/
theorem algebra_318903 (n : ℕ) :
    ∑ i in Finset.range n, (2 * i + 1) * (2 * i + 3) * (2 * i + 5) =
    n * (2 * n ^ 3 + 8 * n ^ 2 + 7 * n - 2) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] From the given, we have $x-a=b-x=2 x-b$, that is
$$
b=\frac{3 x}{2}, \quad \text{ and } \quad x=b-a .
$$
$\therefore \frac{b-a}{b}=\frac{x}{\frac{3 x}{2}}$, which means $1-\frac{a}{b}=\frac{2}{3}$, thus $\frac{a}{b}=\frac{1}{3}$. Therefore, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
10-19 The first four terms of an arithmetic sequence are $a, x, b, 2x$, then the ratio of $a$ to $b$ is 
(A) $\frac{1}{4}$.
(B) $\frac{1}{3}$.
(C) $\frac{1}{2}$.
(D) $\frac{2}{3}$.
(E) 2 .
(38th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1987)
informal_proof:
Let $a, b,$ and $x$ be real numbers, with $a \neq 0$ and $b \neq 0$.
We are given that there exists a real number $d$ such that:
\begin{align*} \label{eq:1} x &= a + d \\ b &= x + d \\ 2x &= b + d\end{align*}
Our goal is to prove that $a/b = 1/3$.

From the first equation, we have $x = a + d$.
Substituting this expression for $x$ into the second equation gives $b = (a + d) + d$, which simplifies to $b = a + 2d$.

Now, we substitute the expression for $x$ from the first equation ($x = a + d$) and the expression for $b$ derived from the second equation ($b = a + 2d$) into the third equation ($2x = b + d$).
This yields:
$2(a + d) = (a + 2d) + d$
Expanding both sides, we get:
$2a + 2d = a + 3d$

To find a relationship between $a$ and $d$, we can rearrange this equation. Subtracting $a$ from both sides gives:
$a + 2d = 3d$
Subtracting $2d$ from both sides gives:
$a = d$

Now that we know $d = a$, we can substitute this back into the equation $b = a + 2d$.
$b = a + 2a$
$b = 3a$

Finally, we can compute the ratio $a/b$. Since $b = 3a$, we have:
$\frac{a}{b} = \frac{a}{3a}$
Given that $a \neq 0$, we can cancel $a$ from the numerator and the denominator:
$\frac{a}{b} = \frac{1}{3}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10-19 The first four terms of an arithmetic sequence are $a, x, b, 2x$, then the ratio of $a$ to $b$ is 
(A) $\frac{1}{4}$.
(B) $\frac{1}{3}$.
(C) $\frac{1}{2}$.
(D) $\frac{2}{3}$.
(E) 2 .
(38th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1987) -/
theorem algebra_247224 {a b x : ℝ} (ha : a ≠ 0) (hb : b ≠ 0)
    (h : ∃ d, x = a + d ∧ b = x + d ∧ 2 * x = b + d) :
    a / b = 1 / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_247224 {a b x : ℝ} (ha : a ≠ 0) (hb : b ≠ 0)
    (h : ∃ d, x = a + d ∧ b = x + d ∧ 2 * x = b + d) :
    a / b = 1 / 3 := by 
  rcases h with ⟨d, hx1, hx2, hx3⟩
  have eq2 : b = a + 2 * d := by
    have eq1 : x = a + d := hx1
    linarith [hx2, eq1]

  have eq3 : 2 * (a + d) = (a + 2 * d) + d := by
    have eq1 : x = a + d := hx1
    have eq2' : b = a + 2 * d := eq2
    linarith [hx3, eq1, eq2']

  have ha_eq_d : a = d := by 
    linarith

  have hb_eq : b = 3 * a := by 
    rw [show d = a by linarith [ha_eq_d]] at eq2
    linarith

  have h1 : a / b = 1 / 3 := by
    rw [hb_eq]
    field_simp [ha]
    <;> linarith

  exact h1

soln_description:
Solution. We will construct the corresponding regions (Fig. 3.8) and determine the appropriate limits of integration from them, omitting the systems of inequalities. Thus:

a) $S=\int_{D} \int d x d y=\int_{0}^{3} d x \int_{0}^{x \sqrt{9-x^{2}}} d y=$

$=\left.\int_{0}^{3} d x \cdot y\right|_{0} ^{x \sqrt{9-x^{2}}}=\int_{0}^{3} x \sqrt{9-x^{2}} d x=$

$=-\int_{0}^{3} \frac{1}{2}\left(9-x^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} d\left(9-x^{2}\right)=$

$=-\left.\frac{1}{3}\left(9-x^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}\right|_{0} ^{3}=9 ;$

b) $S=\iint_{D} d x d y=$

$$
=\int_{0}^{3}\left(2 x-x^{2}+3-x^{2}+4 x-3\right) d x=
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_446938f1e4808e7d6e07g-052.jpg?height=569&width=431&top_left_y=1128&top_left_x=2037)

Fig. 3.9

$$
=\left.\left(-\frac{2 x^{3}}{3}+3 x^{2}\right)\right|_{0} ^{3}=9
$$

Answer. a) $S=9 ;$ b) $S=9$.
informal_statement:
Example 6. Calculate the areas of figures bounded by the curves:

a) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}y=x \sqrt{9-x^{2}} \\ y=0(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 3)\end{array}\right.$

b) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}y=2 x-x^{2}+3 \\ y=x^{2}-4 x+3\end{array}\right.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 6. Calculate the areas of figures bounded by the curves:

a) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}y=x \sqrt{9-x^{2}} \\ y=0(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 3)\end{array}\right.$

b) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}y=2 x-x^{2}+3 \\ y=x^{2}-4 x+3\end{array}\right.$ -/
theorem calculus_148849 (f g : ℝ → ℝ)
  (hf : f = λ x => x * sqrt (9 - x ^ 2)) (hg : g = λ x => 0)
  (hfg : ∀ x, f x ≥ g x) :
  ∫ x in (0)..3, f x = 9 := by

soln_description:
33. From the conditions, we know that \( m \) is a fourth power, so we can set
$$m=2^{4 a_{2}} \cdot 3^{4 a_{3}} \cdot 5^{4 a_{5}} \cdot 7^{4 a_{7}} \cdots \cdots$$

where \(\alpha_{2}, \alpha_{3}, \alpha_{5}, \alpha_{7}, \cdots\) are non-negative integers. And
$$d(m)=\left(4 \alpha_{2}+1\right)\left(4 \alpha_{3}+1\right) \cdots$$

is an odd number, hence \(\alpha_{2}=0\), and
$$1=\frac{4 \alpha_{3}+1}{3^{a_{3}}} \cdot \frac{4 \alpha_{5}+1}{5^{a_{5}}} \cdot \frac{4 \alpha_{7}+1}{7^{\alpha_{7}}} \cdots=x_{3} x_{5} x_{7} \cdots$$

where
$$x_{3}=\frac{4 \alpha_{3}+1}{3^{a_{3}}}, x_{5}=\frac{4 \alpha_{5}+1}{5^{a_{5}}}, \cdots$$

When \(\alpha_{3}=1\), \(x_{3}=\frac{5}{3}\); when \(\alpha_{3}=0\) or 2, \(x_{3}=1\); and when \(\alpha_{3} \geqslant 3\), \(3^{\alpha_{3}} > 4 \alpha_{3}+1\), so in this case \(x_{3}<1\). For \(p > 5\), where \(p\) is a prime, when \(\alpha_{p}=0\), \(x_{p}=1\), and when \(\alpha_{p}=1\), \(p^{\alpha_{p}}>5=4 \alpha_{p}+1\), so \(x_{p}<1\); and when \(\alpha_{p} \geqslant 2\), \(x_{p}<\frac{9}{25}\).

The above discussion shows: if \(\alpha_{3} \neq 1\), then
$$x_{3}=x_{5}=x_{7}=\cdots=1$$

Thus,
$$\alpha_{3}=0 \text{ or } 2, \alpha_{5}=0 \text{ or } 1,$$

and
$$\alpha_{7}=\alpha_{11}=\cdots=0$$

That is,
$$m=1,3^{8}, 5^{4} \text{ or } 45^{4} \text{. }$$

If \(\alpha_{3}=1\), then \(3 \mid m\), at this time, from \(m=d(m)^{4}\), we know
$$m=5^{4} \times\left(4 \alpha_{5}+1\right)^{4} \times\left(4 \alpha_{7}+1\right)^{4} \cdots$$

Thus, there exists a prime \(p \geqslant 5\) such that \(3 \mid 4 \alpha_{p}+1\), which requires \(\alpha_{p} \geqslant 2\), hence \(x_{p}<\frac{9}{25}\). This leads to
$$x_{3} x_{5} x_{7} \cdots \leqslant \frac{5}{3} \times \frac{9}{25}=\frac{3}{5}<1$$

a contradiction.
Therefore,
$$m=1,5^{4}, 3^{8}, 3^{8} \cdot 5^{4}$$
(Direct verification shows that they indeed satisfy the conditions).
informal_statement:
33 Find all positive integers $m$ such that $m=d(m)^{4}$.

Find all positive integers $m$ such that $m=d(m)^{4}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 33 Find all positive integers $m$ such that $m=d(m)^{4}$.

Find all positive integers $m$ such that $m=d(m)^{4}$. -/
theorem number_theory_7902 :
    {m : ℕ | m > 0 ∧ m = (Nat.divisors m).card ^ 4} =
    {1, 5 ^ 4, 3 ^ 8, 3 ^ 8 * 5 ^ 4} := by

informal_statement: Let $a, b > 0$ such that $a + b = \frac{1}{2}$. Prove that $\frac{1}{a^2 + b^2} + \frac{10}{\sqrt{a}} + \frac{10}{\sqrt{b}} \geq 48$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $a, b > 0$ such that $a + b = \frac{1}{2}$. Prove that $\frac{1}{a^2 + b^2} + \frac{10}{\sqrt{a}} + \frac{10}{\sqrt{b}} \geq 48$. -/
theorem inequalities_1355
    (a b : ℝ)
    (ha : 0 < a)
    (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : a + b = 1 / 2) :
    48 ≤ 1 / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) + 10 / sqrt a + 10 / sqrt b := by

soln_description:
Prove that because $l^{2}+m^{2}=n^{2}$, we have $l^{2}=n^{2}-m^{2}=(n+m)(n-m)$.
Since $l$ is a prime number, and $n+m>n-m>0$, then $n+m=l^{2}, n-m=1$.
Thus, $l^{2}=2 m+1,2 m=l^{2}-1$.
Therefore, $2(l+m+1)=2 l+2 m+2$ $=l^{2}+2 l+1=(l+1)^{2}$, which means $2(l+m+1)$ is a perfect square.
informal_statement:
Example 2 Given that the lengths of the two legs of a right triangle are $l$ and $m$, and the hypotenuse is $n$, and $l$, $m$, and $n$ are all positive integers, with $l$ being a prime number. Prove: $2(l+m+1)$ is a perfect square.
$(1985$, Shanghai Junior High School Mathematics Competition)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 2 Given that the lengths of the two legs of a right triangle are $l$ and $m$, and the hypotenuse is $n$, and $l$, $m$, and $n$ are all positive integers, with $l$ being a prime number. Prove: $2(l+m+1)$ is a perfect square.
$(1985$, Shanghai Junior High School Mathematics Competition) -/
theorem number_theory_298624 (l m n : ℕ) (h₀ : l > 0) (h₁ : m > 0) (h₂ : n > 0)
    (h₃ : l^2 + m^2 = n^2) (h₄ : Nat.Prime l) :
    IsSquare (2 * (l + m + 1)) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] If we first paint point 1 red, we can obtain 25 red points $\{1,2,4,8,16, 32,64,128,256,512,224,448,96,192,384,768,736,672,544,288, 576,352,704,608,416\}$. This indicates that the maximum number of red points is no less than 25.

When the first red point is the $m$-th point, the set of all red points is $\left\{m 2^{k}(\bmod 800) \mid k=\right.$ $0,1,2, \cdots\}$. Since $2^{4}=16 \equiv L(\bmod 5)$, we have $2^{4 h} \equiv 1(\bmod 5)$. Therefore,
$$
2^{4} \equiv 16,2^{8} \equiv 6,2^{12} \equiv 21,2^{16} \equiv 11,2^{20} \equiv 1(\bmod 25)
$$

Thus, we get
$$
2^{25} \equiv 32 \quad(\bmod 800) .
$$

Therefore,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left\{m 2^{k}(\bmod 800) \mid k=0,1,2, \cdots\right\} \subset \\
\left\{m 2^{k}(\bmod 800) \mid k=0,1,2, \cdots, 24\right\} .
\end{array}
$$

This means that when we first paint the $m$-th point red, the number of all red points obtained does not exceed 25. In summary, the maximum number of red points is 25.
informal_statement: 9.29 Suppose there are 800 points on a circle, labeled $1, 2, \cdots$, 800 in a clockwise direction, dividing the circle into 800 arcs. Now, choose any one point and color it red, then proceed to color other points red according to the following rule: if the $k$-th point has been colored red, then move $k$ arcs in a clockwise direction and color the point reached red, and continue this process. How many red points can be obtained at most on the circle? Explain your reasoning.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9.29 Suppose there are 800 points on a circle, labeled $1, 2, \cdots$, 800 in a clockwise direction, dividing the circle into 800 arcs. Now, choose any one point and color it red, then proceed to color other points red according to the following rule: if the $k$-th point has been colored red, then move $k$ arcs in a clockwise direction and color the point reached red, and continue this process. How many red points can be obtained at most on the circle? Explain your reasoning. -/
theorem number_theory_151027 (red : Fin 800 → Bool) (h₀ : ∀ i, red i → red (i + i)) :
    {i | red i}.encard ≤ 25 := by

soln_description:
$$
y_{2}, \cdots, y_{5} \text { get }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
b_{11} x_{1} y_{1}+b_{12} x_{2} y_{1}+\cdots+b_{15} x_{5} y_{1}=x_{1} y_{1}, \\
\cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
b_{51} x_{1} y_{5}+b_{52} x_{2} y_{5}+\cdots+b_{55} x_{5} y_{5}=x_{5} y_{5},
\end{array}\right.
$$
Multiply each by $y_{1}$,
Solution: From $\left\{\begin{array}{l}b_{11} x_{1}+b_{12} x_{2}+\cdots+b_{15} x_{5}=x_{1}, \\ \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\ b_{51} x_{1}+b_{52} x_{2}+\cdots+b_{55} x_{5}=x_{5}\end{array}\right.$

Summing up, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(b_{11} y_{1}+\cdots+b_{51} y_{5}\right) x_{1}+\cdots+\left(b_{15} y_{1}+\cdots+b_{55} y_{5}\right) x_{5} \\
= & x_{1} y_{1}+\cdots+x_{5} y_{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

If $b_{i j}=b_{j i}$, then $x_{1} y_{1}+\cdots+x_{5} y_{5}=2\left(x_{1} y_{1}+\cdots+x_{5} y_{5}\right)$, solving gives $x_{1} y_{1}+\cdots+x_{5} y_{5}=0$. Therefore, when $b_{i j}=b_{j i}$, the conclusion holds.

By definition, $1+n a_{1}=b_{1} n=b_{n 1}=b_{(n-1) 1}\left(1+a_{n}\right)=b_{1(n-1)}(1+$ $\left.a_{n}\right)=\left[1+(n-1) a_{1}\right]\left(1+a_{n}\right)$, we get $a_{n}=\frac{a_{1}}{1+(n-1) a_{1}}$.
Now verify that $a_{n}=\frac{a_{1}}{1+(n-1) a_{1}}$ when $b_{i j}=b_{j i}$.
Assume $i>j$, then
$$
\begin{aligned}
b_{i j} & =\prod_{1 \leq k \leq i}\left(1+j a_{k}\right)=\prod_{k=1}^{i} \frac{1+(j+k-1) a_{1}}{1+(k-1) a_{1}} \\
& =\frac{\prod_{k=1-i+j}^{j}\left[1+(i+k-1) a_{1}\right]}{\prod_{k=1}^{i}\left[1+(k-1) a_{1}\right]} \\
& =\frac{\prod_{k=1}^{j}\left[1+(i+k-1) a_{1}\right]}{\prod_{k=1}^{j}\left[1+(k-1) a_{1}\right]} \cdot \frac{\prod_{k=1-i+j}^{j}\left[1+(i+k-1) a_{1}\right]}{\prod_{k=j+1}^{j+i}\left[1+(k-1) a_{1}\right]} \\
& =\prod_{k=1}^{j} \frac{1+(i+k-1) a_{1}}{1+(k-1) a_{1}}=b_{i j},
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the required real sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}=\left\{\frac{a_{1}}{1+(n-1) a_{1}}\right\}$.
If $a_{3}=\cdots=a_{5}=0$, it can be deduced that $x_{1}=\cdots=x_{5}=0, y_{1}=\cdots=y_{5}=0$, hence the conclusion holds.
informal_statement:
20 For a given integer $a_{1}(\neq-1)$, find a sequence of real numbers $\left\{a_{n}\right\}\left(a_{i} \neq 0\right.$, $i=1,2, \cdots, 5)$, such that: if $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{5}, y_{1}, y_{2}, \cdots, y_{5}$ satisfy
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
b_{11} x_{1}+b_{12} x_{2}+\cdots+b_{15} x_{5}=x_{1}, \\
\cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
b_{51} x_{1}+b_{52} x_{2}+\cdots+b_{55} x_{5}=x_{5} ;
\end{array}\right. \\
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
b_{11} y_{1}+b_{12} y_{2}+\cdots+b_{15} y_{5}=2 y_{1}, \\
\cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
b_{51} y_{1}+b_{52} y_{2}+\cdots+b_{55} y_{5}=2 y_{5},
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}\right.
$$

and

then $x_{1} y_{1}+x_{2} y_{2}+\cdots+x_{5} y_{5}=0$, where $b_{i j}=\prod_{1 \leq k \leq i}\left(1+j a_{k}\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 20 For a given integer $a_{1}(\neq-1)$, find a sequence of real numbers $\left\{a_{n}\right\}\left(a_{i} \neq 0\right.$, $i=1,2, \cdots, 5)$, such that: if $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{5}, y_{1}, y_{2}, \cdots, y_{5}$ satisfy
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
b_{11} x_{1}+b_{12} x_{2}+\cdots+b_{15} x_{5}=x_{1}, \\
\cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
b_{51} x_{1}+b_{52} x_{2}+\cdots+b_{55} x_{5}=x_{5} ;
\end{array}\right. \\
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
b_{11} y_{1}+b_{12} y_{2}+\cdots+b_{15} y_{5}=2 y_{1}, \\
\cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
b_{51} y_{1}+b_{52} y_{2}+\cdots+b_{55} y_{5}=2 y_{5},
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}\right.
$$

and

then $x_{1} y_{1}+x_{2} y_{2}+\cdots+x_{5} y_{5}=0$, where $b_{i j}=\prod_{1 \leq k \leq i}\left(1+j a_{k}\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_245939 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : a 1 ≠ -1)
    (x y : Fin 5 → ℝ) (hx : ∀ i, x i ≠ 0) (hy : ∀ i, y i ≠ 0)
    (hxy : ∀ i, ∑ j : Fin 5, (a 1 / (1 + (j.1 - 1) * a 1)) * x j = x i)
    (hxy' : ∀ i, ∑ j : Fin 5, (a 1 / (1 + (j.1 - 1) * a 1)) * y j = 2 * y i) :
    ∑ i : Fin 5, x i * y i = 0 := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Since $0 . \dot{a} b \dot{c}=\frac{a b c}{999}$, and because $999=3^{3} \times 37$, therefore, when the positive integer $a b c$ is neither divisible by 3 nor by 37, $\frac{a b c}{999}$ is in its simplest form, and the numerator is $a b c$. Among the 999 positive integers from 1 to 999, there are $\frac{999}{3}=333$ numbers divisible by 3; $\frac{999}{37}=27$ numbers divisible by 37; and 9 numbers divisible by $3 \times 37$. By the principle of inclusion and exclusion, there are $999-333-27+9=648$ such different numerators.

Next, consider which of the excluded numbers, either multiples of 3 or 37 or both, can still serve as the numerators of the simplest fractions.

Since $37^{2}>999$, any multiple of 37, when simplified by dividing by 37, will no longer be a multiple of 37. Therefore, any multiple of 37 cannot be the numerator of the simplest fraction.

However, among the multiples of 3, there are some that can be simplified by dividing by $3^{3}$ to produce new numerators, i.e., the following 12 numbers: $\square$
$$
\{81 k \mid k=1,2, \cdots, 12\}
$$

When simplified by dividing by 999, the simplest fractions obtained are
$$
\frac{3 k}{37}, k=1,2, \cdots, 12 \text {. }
$$

Their numerators are $3,6,9, \cdots, 36$. These are all multiples of 3 and are certainly different from the previous ones. Therefore, the total number of different numerators that meet the requirements is 660.
informal_statement:
1.9 Let $s$ be the set of all rational numbers $r$ that satisfy the following conditions:
$$
\text { (1) } 0<r<1 \text {; }
$$
(2) $r=0 . a b c a b c a b c \cdots=0 . a b \dot{c}$, where $a, b, c$ are not necessarily distinct.

How many different numerators are there when the numbers $r$ in $s$ are written in their simplest form?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 1.9 Let $s$ be the set of all rational numbers $r$ that satisfy the following conditions:
$$
\text { (1) } 0<r<1 \text {; }
$$
(2) $r=0 . a b c a b c a b c \cdots=0 . a b \dot{c}$, where $a, b, c$ are not necessarily distinct.

How many different numerators are there when the numbers $r$ in $s$ are written in their simplest form? -/
theorem number_theory_254615 :
  Set.ncard {n : ℕ | ∃ r : ℚ, 0 < r ∧ r < 1 ∧ r.num = n ∧
    ∃ a b c : ℕ, r = (a * 100 + b * 10 + c) / 999} = 660 := by

soln_description: g(k) + g(1-k) = 1, so the sum is 997 + g(1/2) = 997 1/2. 27th CanMO 1995 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 15 June 2002
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 27th CanMO 1995 Problem 1 Find g(1/1996) + g(2/1996) + g(3/1996) + ... + g(1995/1996) where g(x) = 9 x /(3 + 9 x ). -/
theorem algebra_142372 {g : ℝ → ℝ} (hg : ∀ x, g x = 9 * x / (3 + 9 * x)) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 1995, g ((i + 1) / 1996) = 997.5 := by

informal_proof:
We are given the complex numbers $z = 2 + \sqrt{2} - (3 + 3\sqrt{2})i$ and $c = 2 - 3i$. The complex number $w$ is defined by the transformation $w = (z - c) \cdot e^{i \frac{\pi}{4}} + c$, which represents rotating the point $z$ around the point $c$ by an angle of $\frac{\pi}{4}$ in the counter-clockwise direction.

To find $w$, we substitute the given values of $z$ and $c$ into the formula:
$w = \left( (2 + \sqrt{2} - (3 + 3\sqrt{2})i) - (2 - 3i) \right) \cdot e^{i \frac{\pi}{4}} + (2 - 3i)$.

First, we simplify the term $z-c$:
$z - c = (2 + \sqrt{2} - 2) + (-3 - 3\sqrt{2} - (-3))i$
$z - c = \sqrt{2} + (-3 - 3\sqrt{2} + 3)i$
$z - c = \sqrt{2} - 3\sqrt{2}i$.

Next, we evaluate the rotation factor $e^{i \frac{\pi}{4}}$ using Euler's formula, $e^{i\theta} = \cos\theta + i\sin\theta$:
$e^{i \frac{\pi}{4}} = \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) + i\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)$.
Since $\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$ and $\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$, we have:
$e^{i \frac{\pi}{4}} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$.

Now, we compute the product $(z-c) \cdot e^{i \frac{\pi}{4}}$:
$(\sqrt{2} - 3\sqrt{2}i) \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + i\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)$
$= \sqrt{2}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) + \sqrt{2}\left(i\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) - 3\sqrt{2}i\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) - 3\sqrt{2}i\left(i\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)$
$= \frac{2}{2} + i\frac{2}{2} - i\frac{6}{2} - i^2\frac{6}{2}$
$= 1 + i - 3i - (-1)\frac{6}{2}$
$= 1 + i - 3i + 3$
$= (1+3) + (1-3)i$
$= 4 - 2i$.

Finally, we add $c$ to this result to find $w$:
$w = (4 - 2i) + (2 - 3i)$
$w = (4+2) + (-2-3)i$
$w = 6 - 5i$.

Thus, we have shown that $w = 6 - 5i$.
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

theorem calculus_23465 {z c : ℂ} (hz : z = 2 + Real.sqrt 2 - (3 + 3 * Real.sqrt 2) * .I)
  (hc : c = 2 - 3 * .I) (w : ℂ) (hw : w = (z - c) * (Complex.exp (Complex.I * Real.pi / 4)) + c) :
  w = 6 - 5 * .I := by 
  rw [hw, hz, hc]
  simp [Complex.ext_iff, Complex.add_re, Complex.add_im, Complex.mul_re, Complex.mul_im, 
        Complex.exp_re, Complex.exp_im, Complex.I_re, Complex.I_im, mul_add, mul_comm]
  ring_nf
  <;> simp [Real.sqrt_sq, Real.sin_pi_div_four, Real.cos_pi_div_four]
  <;> ring_nf
  <;> norm_num
  <;> ring

soln_description:
If $x=0$, then from $y=y^{2}$ we get $y=0,1$ and $(x, y)=(0,0),(0,1)$ are rational solutions. For the case $x \neq 0$, using the notation $y / x=r$, we have $y=r x$. Substituting this and simplifying by $x$,

$$
x=\frac{1+r}{1+r^{2}}
$$

is obtained, and thus

$$
y=\frac{r+r^{2}}{1+r^{2}}
$$

Therefore, if $(x, y)$ is a rational solution and $x \neq 0$, then $r$ is also rational and

$$
(x, y)=\left(\frac{1+r}{1+r^{2}}, \quad \frac{r+r^{2}}{1+r^{2}}\right)
$$

Furthermore, if $r$ is any rational number, we can verify by direct substitution that

$$
\left(\frac{1+r}{1+r^{2}}, \quad \frac{r+r^{2}}{1+r^{2}}\right)
$$

is indeed a solution, and specifically a rational solution, to the equation.
informal_statement:
Let's find the rational solutions of the equation

$$
x+y=x^{2}+y^{2}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let's find the rational solutions of the equation

$$
x+y=x^{2}+y^{2}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_154482 (x y : ℚ) :
    x + y = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 ↔ ∃ r, x = (1 + r) / (1 + r ^ 2) ∧ y = (r + r ^ 2) / (1 + r ^ 2) := by

informal_statement:
3. If $n$ is a positive integer, then we say that $n$ is deficient if $\sigma(n)2 n$. Every integer is either deficient, perfect, or abundant.
a) Find the six smallest abundant positive integers.
b) Find the smallest odd abundant positive integer.
c) Show that every prime power is deficient.
d) Show that any divisor of a deficient or perfect number is deficient.
e) Show that any multiple of an abundant or perfect number is abundant.
f) Show that if $n=2^{m-1}\left(2^{m}-1\right)$, where $m$ is a positive integer such that $2^{m}-1$ is composite, then $n$ is abundant.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def is_abundant (n : ℕ) := ∑ d in n.divisors, d > 2 * n

def is_perfect (n : ℕ) := ∑ d in n.divisors, d = 2 * n

def is_deficient (n : ℕ) := ∑ d in n.divisors, d < 2 * n

/- 3. If $n$ is a positive integer, then we say that $n$ is deficient if $\sigma(n)2 n$. Every integer is either deficient, perfect, or abundant.
a) Find the six smallest abundant positive integers.
b) Find the smallest odd abundant positive integer.
c) Show that every prime power is deficient.
d) Show that any divisor of a deficient or perfect number is deficient.
e) Show that any multiple of an abundant or perfect number is abundant.
f) Show that if $n=2^{m-1}\left(2^{m}-1\right)$, where $m$ is a positive integer such that $2^{m}-1$ is composite, then $n$ is abundant. -/
theorem number_theory_4919 :
    (Nat.nth {n | is_abundant n} 0 = 12 ∧
     Nat.nth {n | is_abundant n} 1 = 18 ∧
     Nat.nth {n | is_abundant n} 2 = 20 ∧
     Nat.nth {n | is_abundant n} 3 = 22 ∧
     Nat.nth {n | is_abundant n} 4 = 26 ∧
     Nat.nth {n | is_abundant n} 5 = 30) ∧
    (Nat.nth {n | Odd n ∧ is_abundant n} 0 = 15) ∧
    ( ∀ n p k : ℕ, Nat.Prime p → n = p ^ k → is_deficient n) ∧
    ( ∀ n d : ℕ, d ∣ n → (is_deficient n ∨ is_perfect n) → is_deficient d) ∧
    ( ∀ n m : ℕ, n = 2 ^ (m - 1) * (2 ^ m - 1) → m > 0 → ¬Nat.Prime (2 ^ m - 1) → is_abundant n) := by

soln_description:
Solution. As a result of one or several consecutive games, the Scientist may end up with no money at all (state 0), 10 rubles, 20, 30, 40 rubles, or he may win enough money to buy a bus ticket (state A). The possible transitions between states are schematically represented by a graph (Fig. 7). The probabilities of transitions from one state to another are labeled on the corresponding edges of the graph. Let \( x_{1} \) be the probability of eventually transitioning from state 10 to state A. Similarly, let \( x_{2}, x_{3} \), and \( x_{4} \) be the probabilities of reaching state A from states 20, 30, and 40, respectively. We are interested in \( x_{2} \).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_11f8b78b86004d31b3e4g-06.jpg?height=572&width=734&top_left_y=642&top_left_x=1186)

Fig. 7. Graph of transitions from state to state

It is impossible to transition directly from state 10 to state A, but one can reach state 30 with probability \( p \), and from there to A. Therefore,

\[
x_{1} = q \cdot 0 + p x_{3}
\]

where \( q = 1 - p \) is the probability that the ticket will not contain a win.

Similarly analyzing states 20, 30, and 40, we obtain three more equations, which together with the first one form the system

\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x_{1} = p x_{3} \\
x_{2} = p x_{4} + q x_{1} \\
x_{3} = p + q x_{2} \\
x_{4} = p + q x_{3}
\end{array}\right.
\]

Substituting the expressions for \( x_{1} \) and \( x_{4} \) into the second equation:

\[
x_{2} = p \left( p + q x_{3} \right) + q p x_{3} = p^{2} + 2 p q x_{3}
\]

Now substituting the expression for \( x_{3} \) and we get

\[
x_{2} = p^{2} + 2 p q \left( p + q x_{2} \right)
\]

from which

\[
x_{2} = \frac{p^{2}(1 + 2 q)}{1 - 2 p q^{2}} = \frac{p^{2}(1 + 2 - 2 p)}{1 - 2 p (1 - p)^{2}} = \frac{3 p^{2} - 2 p^{3}}{1 - 2 p + 4 p^{2} - 2 p^{3}}
\]

For \( p = 0.1 \), we find: \( x_{2} = \frac{14}{419} \approx 0.033 \).

Answer: approximately \( 0.033 \).
informal_statement: 10. Lottery. (From 7th grade, 3 points) It so happened that the Absent-Minded Scholar had only 20 rubles left, and he needed to buy a bus ticket to go home. The ticket costs 45 rubles. Near the bus stop, instant lottery tickets are sold for exactly 10 rubles each. With a probability of \( p = 0.1 \), a ticket contains a win of 30 rubles, and there are no other prizes. The Scholar decided to take a risk, as he had nothing to lose. Find the probability that the Absent-Minded Scholar will be able to win enough money to buy a bus ticket.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 10. Lottery. (From 7th grade, 3 points) It so happened that the Absent-Minded Scholar had only 20 rubles left, and he needed to buy a bus ticket to go home. The ticket costs 45 rubles. Near the bus stop, instant lottery tickets are sold for exactly 10 rubles each. With a probability of \( p = 0.1 \), a ticket contains a win of 30 rubles, and there are no other prizes. The Scholar decided to take a risk, as he had nothing to lose. Find the probability that the Absent-Minded Scholar will be able to win enough money to buy a bus ticket. -/
theorem algebra_266977 (p : ℝ) (hp : p = 0.1) :
    (1 - (1 - p) ^ 20) / 419 = 14 / 419 := by

soln_description:
Solution
Suppose that $(x, y)$ is a pair of integers that satisfies the equation given in the question. That is, suppose that $x$ and $y$ are integers such that
$$
\sqrt{x-\sqrt{x+23}}=2 \sqrt{2}-y .
$$

Squaring both sides of equation (1), we obtain
$$
x-\sqrt{x+23}=8-4 \sqrt{2} y+y^{2} .
$$

We can rewrite equation (2) as
$$
\sqrt{x+23}=4 \sqrt{2} y-\left(8+y^{2}-x\right) .
$$

Since $x$ and $y$ are integers, $8+y^{2}-x$ is an integer. For convenience we put $z=8+y^{2}-x$. Then equation (3) becomes
$$
\sqrt{x+23}=4 \sqrt{2} y-z \text {. }
$$

By squaring both sides of equation (4), we obtain
$$
x+23=32 y^{2}-8 \sqrt{2} y z+z^{2} .
$$

Equation (5) may be rearranged to give
$$
8 \sqrt{2} y z=32 y^{2}+z^{2}-x-23 .
$$

Now, if $y z \neq 0$, equation (6) implies that
$$
\sqrt{2}=\frac{32 y^{2}+z^{2}-x-23}{8 y z} .
$$

Because $x, y$ and $z$ are integers, equation (7) implies that $\sqrt{2}$ is rational. Since $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational (see Problem 22.1), we deduce that $y z=0$. It follows that $y=0$ or $z=0$.
Suppose first that $y=0$. It then follows from equation (2) that
$$
x-\sqrt{x+23}=8 .
$$

We leave it as an exercise for the reader to show that equation (8) does not have an integer solution (see Problem 22.2).

Now suppose that $z=0$. Then
$$
8+y^{2}-x=0 .
$$

It now follows from equations (3) and (9) that
$$
\sqrt{x+23}=4 \sqrt{2} y \text {. }
$$

Squaring both sides of equation (10), we obtain $x+23=32 y^{2}$ and hence
$$
x=32 y^{2}-23 \text {. }
$$

We now use equation (11) to substitute $32 y^{2}-23$ for $x$ in equation (9). In this way we obtain
$$
8+y^{2}-\left(32 y^{2}-23\right)=0 .
$$

Equation (12) may be rearranged to give
$$
31\left(1-y^{2}\right)=0 \text {. }
$$

Hence, $1-y^{2}=0$. Therefore, $y=-1$ or $y=1$. In either case, it follows from the equation (11) that $x=9$.

It seems that we have found two pairs of integers $(9,-1)$ and $(9,1)$ that satisfy equation (1). However, we obtained these solutions by squaring both sides of equations (1), (4) and (10).
Squaring both sides of an equation is an operation that runs the risk of introducing spurious solutions. Therefore we need to check whether or not $(9,-1)$ and $(9,1)$ are solutions of the original equation.

We leave it to the reader (see Problem 22.3) to check that $(9,1)$ is a solution of equation (1), but $(9,-1)$ is not a solution.
It follows that there is just one pair of integers $(x, y)$, namely $(9,1)$, that satisfies the equation $\sqrt{x-\sqrt{x+23}}=2 \sqrt{2}-y$.

For INVESTIGATION
22.1 The solution above uses the fact that $\sqrt{2}$ is not a rational number. This means that there do not exist integers $p$ and $q$ such that
$$
\sqrt{2}=\frac{p}{q} .
$$

Find a proof of this fact. That is, find a proof in a book or on the internet, or ask your teacher.
22.2 Show that the equation
$$
x-\sqrt{x+23}=8
$$
does not have an integer solution.
[Hint: rewrite this equation as $x-8=\sqrt{x+23}$. Square both sides of this equation. Then consider the solutions of the quadratic equation that you obtain.]
22.3 Show that $x=9, y=1$ is a solution of the equation $\sqrt{x-\sqrt{x+23}}=2 \sqrt{2}-y$, but $x=9, y=-1$ is not a solution.
informal_statement:
22. How many pairs of integers $(x, y)$ satisfy the equation $\sqrt{x-\sqrt{x+23}}=2 \sqrt{2}-y$ ?
A 0
B 1
C 4
D 8
E infinitely many
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 22. How many pairs of integers $(x, y)$ satisfy the equation $\sqrt{x-\sqrt{x+23}}=2 \sqrt{2}-y$ ?
A 0
B 1
C 4
D 8
E infinitely many -/
theorem algebra_243625 (x y : ℤ) :
    Real.sqrt (x - Real.sqrt (x + 23)) = 2 * Real.sqrt 2 - y ↔ (x = 23 ∧ y = 1) := by

soln_description:
Proof: Let $x=abc, y=bcd, z=acd, t=bcd$, then the inequality becomes
$$\sum_{\text {cyc }} \frac{1}{3-x} \leq 2 \Leftrightarrow \sum_{c y c} \frac{1-x}{3-x} \geq 0$$

According to the AM-GM inequality, we have
$$x+y=ab(c+d) \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) \sqrt{2\left(c^{2}+d^{2}\right)} \leq\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}<\frac{9}{4}$$

Without loss of generality, assume $x \leq y \leq z \leq t$. First, we consider the case $x+y \leq \frac{1}{4}$. It is easy to see that $t=bcd \leq\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}$ and $z \leq 1$. Since $\frac{1}{3-x}$ is an increasing convex function, we have
$$\frac{1}{3-x}+\frac{1}{3-y}+\frac{1}{3-z}+\frac{1}{3-t} \leq \frac{1}{3-1 / 4}+\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{3-1}+\frac{1}{3-\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}<2$$

Now consider the case $x+y \geq \frac{1}{4}$. Since
$$\begin{array}{l}
(1-x)(4 x+3)-(1-y)(4 y+3)=(x-y)(1-4 x-4 y) \geq 0 \\
(3-x)(4 x+3)-(3-y)(4 y+3)=(x-y)(9-4 x-4 y) \leq 0
\end{array}$$

According to Chebyshev's inequality, we have
$$\sum_{c y c} \frac{1-x}{3-x}=\sum_{c y c} \frac{(1-x)(4 x+3)}{(3-x)(4 x+3)} \geq \frac{1}{4}\left(\sum_{c y c}(1-x)(4 x+3)\right)\left(\sum_{c y c} \frac{1}{(3-x)(4 x+3)}\right)$$

Thus, it suffices to prove $\sum_{c y c}(1-x)(4 x+3) \geq 0$ or $S=12+\sum_{c y c} x-4 \sum_{c y c} x^{2} \geq 0$
Since $\sum_{c y c} a^{2}=4$, according to the AM-GM inequality, we have $abcd \leq 1$ and $\sum_{c y c} \frac{1}{a} \geq 4$. Therefore,
$$x+y+z+t=abcd\left(\sum_{c y c} \frac{1}{a}\right) \geq 4 abcd \geq 4 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2} d^{2} \quad(*)$$

Let $m=a^{2}, n=b^{2}, p=c^{2}, q=d^{2}$, then $\sum_{c y c} m=4$. According to $(*)$, we have
$$S \geq 12+4 m b p q-4 \sum_{c y c} m n p$$

Since $x \leq y \leq z \leq t$, then $m \leq n \leq p \leq q$. Let $r=\frac{1}{3}(n+p+q)$, then by the AM-GM inequality, we have $n p+p q+q n \leq 3 r^{2}$, and $n p q \leq t^{3}$. Since $m \leq 1$, we have
$$S=12-4 n p q(1-m)-4 m(n p+p q+q m) \geq 12-4 r^{3}(1-m)+4 m \cdot 3 r^{2}$$

In the above inequality, replace $m$ with $4-3 r$, we have
$$S \geq 4-4(4-3 r) r^{2}-4 r^{3}(3 r-3)=12(r-1)^{2}\left(-r^{2}+2 r+1\right) \geq 0 \text { . }$$

The inequality is proved, equality holds when $a=b=c=d=1$
informal_statement: 57. Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}=4$, prove: $\frac{1}{3-a b c}+\frac{1}{3-b c d}+\frac{1}{3-c d a}+\frac{1}{3-d a b} \leq 2$ (Pham Kim Hung)

/- 57. Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+d^{2}=4$, prove: $\frac{1}{3-a b c}+\frac{1}{3-b c d}+\frac{1}{3-c d a}+\frac{1}{3-d a b} \leq 2$ (Pham Kim Hung) -/
theorem inequalities_597256 (a b c d : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2 = 4) :
    1 / (3 - a * b * c) + 1 / (3 - b * c * d) + 1 / (3 - c * d * a) +
    1 / (3 - d * a * b) ≤ 2 := by

informal_statement: Let $(a_n)_{n \ge 1}$ be a sequence of real numbers defined recursively by $a_1 = a_2 = 1$, $a_3 = 2$, and $a_{n+3} = \frac{a_{n+1} \cdot a_{n+2} + 5}{a_n}$ for all $n \ge 1$. Prove that $a_n \in \mathbb{Z}$ for all $n \ge 1$.

import Mathlib

open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $(a_n)_{n \ge 1}$ be a sequence of real numbers defined recursively by $a_1 = a_2 = 1$, $a_3 = 2$, and $a_{n+3} = \frac{a_{n+1} \cdot a_{n+2} + 5}{a_n}$ for all $n \ge 1$. Prove that $a_n \in \mathbb{Z}$ for all $n \ge 1$. -/
theorem algebra_3272 {a : ℕ → ℝ}
  (ha1 : a 1 = 1) (ha2 : a 2 = 1) (ha3 : a 3 = 2)
  (han : ∀ n ≥ 1, a (n+3) = (a (n+1) * a (n+2) + 5) / a n) :
  ∀ n ≥ 1, ∃ m : ℤ, a n = m := by

soln_description:
7. Let the theorem (see "answers") be true for $n=p$. This means: when mixing mixtures

$$
\left(K_{1}, m_{1}\right),\left(K_{2}, m_{2}\right), \ldots,\left(K_{p}, m_{p}\right)
$$

the resulting mixture is ( $C, m_{1}+m_{2}+\ldots+m_{p}$ ), determined by the condition: $\left(C, m_{1}+\ldots+m_{p}\right)=\left(K_{1}, m_{1}\right)+\left(K_{2}, m_{2}\right)+\ldots+\left(K_{p}, m_{p}\right)$.

We will prove that the theorem is also true for $n=p+1$. Indeed, the mixture resulting from mixing $p+1$ mixtures

$$
\left(K_{1}, m_{1}\right), \ldots,\left(K_{p}, m_{p}\right),\left(K_{p+1}, m_{p+1}\right)
$$

obviously coincides with the mixture that results from mixing two mixtures:

$$
\left(C, m_{1}+\ldots+m_{p}\right) \text { and }\left(K_{p+1}, m_{p+1}\right)
$$

But by problem 1, this mixture is characterized by a material point determined by the condition:

$$
(K, m)=\left(C, m_{1}+\ldots+m_{p}\right)+\left(K_{p+1}, m_{p+1}\right)
$$

If we also take into account the equality (1) written above, we get:

$$
(K, m)=\left(K_{1}, m_{1}\right)+\ldots+\left(K_{p}, m_{p}\right)+\left(K_{p+1}, m_{p+1}\right) .
$$

Thus, the theorem is true for $n=p+1$ if it is true for $n=p$. Moreover, it is true for $n=1$. Therefore, it is true for any natural $n$.
informal_statement: 7. Generalize the theorem from problem 1 to the case of $n$ mixtures $(n>2)$. (O. 117, У. 126, P. 218.)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Generalize the theorem from problem 1 to the case of $n$ mixtures $(n>2)$. (O. 117, У. 126, P. 218.) -/
theorem algebra_258772 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 2) (a b : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i, 0 ≤ a i ∧ a i ≤ 1) (hb : ∀ i, 0 ≤ b i ∧ b i ≤ 1)
    (h : ∑ i, a i * b i = 1) :
    ∃ x : Fin n → ℝ, (∀ i, 0 ≤ x i ∧ x i ≤ 1) ∧ (∑ i, x i = 1) ∧
    (∑ i, a i * x i = 1) ∧ (∑ i, b i * x i = 1) := by

=3 \text {. } \\

$$

We also need to verify that $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}$ are not integers. It is easy to see that $x_{1}\sqrt{2}$, and we need to prove that $x_{3}>2$. Therefore, the smallest $n$ value that makes $x_{n}$ an integer is 4.

(A) 2 ;

soln_description:
4. $-\frac{1}{2}$.

From the condition, when $n \geqslant 2$,
$$
S_{n}^{2}=a_{n}\left(S_{n}-\frac{1}{2}\right)=\left(S_{n}-S_{n-1}\right)\left(S_{n}-\frac{1}{2}\right),
$$

Thus,
$$
\frac{1}{S_{n}}-\frac{1}{S_{n-1}}=2
$$

Therefore,
$$
\frac{1}{S_{n}}=\frac{1}{S_{1}}+2(n-1)=2 n-1,
$$

So, $S_{n}=\frac{1}{2 n-1}$. Hence,
$$
a_{n}=S_{n}-S_{n-1}=\frac{1}{2 n-1}-\frac{1}{2 n-3}=-\frac{2}{(2 n-1)(2 n-3)} .
$$

Therefore,
$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} n^{2} a_{n}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}-\frac{2 n^{2}}{(2 n-1)(2 n-3)}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}-\frac{2}{\left(2-\frac{1}{n}\right)\left(2-\frac{3}{n}\right)}=-\frac{1}{2}
$$
informal_statement: 4. In the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$, $a_{1}=1$. When $n \geqslant 2$, $a_{n}, S_{n}, S_{n}-\frac{1}{2}\left(S_{n}\right.$ is the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$) form a geometric progression, then $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} n^{2} a_{n}=$ $\qquad$

/- 10 (21 points) Given the positive sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=2, a_{n}=\frac{a_{n-2}}{a_{n-1}}$, $n \geqslant 3$. Find the general formula for $a_{n}$.

 -/
theorem algebra_239772 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha : ∀ n, 0 < a n)
